quiz_title: Quiz 1 (due Thursday, Sept. 11 at 11:59 PM): BIOL 1009 (070-082) General Biology (Fall 2025)

questions.question: What should you call your professor?

options.text: "Sue" if you're the informal type, "Dr. Gibson" or "Prof. Gibson" if you prefer to be more formal.

questions.question: True or false: If you end up missing one of the online lecture quizzes for a good reason, such as being sick, you should immediately contact the professor about your situation and request an extension on the quiz.

options.comment: Extensions are not granted for the online lecture quizzes for any reason. Instead, the lowest three quiz scores will be dropped automatically for each student so that you won't have to take a zero on a quiz if you miss one or two due to being sick, having your internet go out at the last moment, etc. So, please do not contact your professor and ask for an extension if you miss an online lecture quiz. It may seem that there is no harm in asking, but it gets really tough for your professor to have to write back individually to several students after every quiz explaining that they won't get an extension because their lowest three quiz scores are being dropped for situations exactly such as theirs. Extensions are not granted for the online lecture quizzes for any reason. Instead, the lowest three quiz scores will be dropped automatically for each student so that you won't have to take a zero on a quiz if you miss one or two due to being sick, having your internet go out at the last moment, etc. So, please do not contact your professor and ask for an extension if you miss an online lecture quiz. It may seem that there is no harm in asking, but it gets really tough for your professor to have to write back individually to several students after every quiz explaining that they won't get an extension because their lowest three quiz scores are being dropped for situations exactly such as theirs.

questions.question: How final course grades will be determined

options.text: is described in the course syllabus. The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned in order to earn different final course grades.
will be determined later in the semester.

questions.question: Why is it important to spend some time answering study questions within a few hours, and again within a few days, of listening to the recordings for a topic?

options.text: The study questions will disappear from the Canvas site within 24 hours after the date for each topic.
Going over the material within a few hours, and again within a few days, is very important to getting the material into your long-term memory.

questions.question: Studies have shown which of the following to be a particularly effective way for most students to learn new material?

options.text: repeatedly going over their notes about the material
repeatedly going back over textbook readings about the material
repeatedly answering questions about the material

questions.question: "Brad has blown off going to his lab session four times. Chloe got covid and, due to having covid, missed four lab sections. Chloe has a note from her doctor stating that she was too sick to attend class during all four of the lab sessions that she missed." Assuming that both Brad and Chloe have done well on all the exams, quizzes, etc., who is on track to pass the course?

options.text: Both Brad and Chloe are on track to pass the course.
Neither. Both Brad and Chloe are not going to pass the course.
Chloe is on track to pass. Brad is going to fail.

questions.question: Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. This means that the information covered in the course is information students will likely need to be successful in their future careers. As a result, committing scholastic dishonesty in this course is not only dis-honorable, but is also likely to negatively impact students' future careers. Because scholastic dishonesty is not tolerated in this course, students found to have committed scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on an exam:

options.text: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
will be given a second chance if they promise not to do it again.
will be given an opportunity to make up some or all of the points they lost by getting a "0" on an exam or other assignment.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are true? 1) The lecture part of the course will cover 25 different topics during the semester. To access the material for each of these topics, students should click on the topic on the homepage of the course Canvas site. In other words, to access the material for Topic 1, click where it says "Topic 1". 2) Students should complete the activities listed on the page for a particular topic by the date for that topic, shown near the end of the course syllabus.
Which of the following looks like a good study plan for an average student hoping to earn an above average grade of "B" or "A" in the course?

options.text: For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 3 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.

For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 1.5 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.
options.comment: This is unlikely to be enough time spent studying outside of class for an average student to earn a grade of "B" or "A".

questions.question: Regarding the online quizzes

options.text: You may use the course handouts to help you answer quiz questions
You may use your notes to help you answer quiz questions
You may use other students to help you answer quiz questions
You may use the web to help you answer quiz questions
You may use your textbook to help you answer quiz questions
All of these answers are correct

questions.question: Is the professor teaching the course available in real time to help you with the course material?

options.text: There will be online office hours each week. Additional help is available by appointment.
The only help available are office hours by appointment.
The only help available are the online office hours.
No, you are out of luck.

questions.question: According to University policy, how many total hours of effort should an average student need to spend each week during the semester to earn a grade of “C” in a 4 credit course, such as BIOL 1009?

options.comment: Correct! Please note that an average student should expect to spend more than 12 hours per week on the course to earn a grade of “B” or “A”. Correct! Please note that an average student should expect to spend more than 12 hours per week on the course to earn a grade of “B” or “A”.

questions.question: Repetition is essential to storing information and concepts in you long-term memory. Therefore,

options.text: it is recommended that you do the assigned reading shortly before watching the recordings. Then, begin answering study questions and reviewing the handouts and your notes within a few hours after watching the recordings, answer more study questions a few days later and again before each exam.
try to learn everything the night before the exam.

questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement regarding recommend priorities in studying for BIOL 1009?

options.text: Your primary focus should be on the material covered in the textbook. For most students, the best way to master this material is to spend a large percentage of their study time on reading the textbook.

Your primary focus should be on the material covered in the recordings and handouts. For most students, the best way to master this material is to spend a large percentage of their study time on answering the study questions.

Your primary focus should be on the material covered in the textbook. For most students, the best way to master this material is to spend a large percentage of their study time on reading the handouts over and over.

Your primary focus should be on the material covered in the recordings and handouts. For most students, the best way to master this material is to spend a large percentage of their study time on reading the handouts over and over.

questions.question: Why is it a good idea to spend a few minutes reviewing the handout and your notes within a few hours, and again within a few days, of listening to the recordings for each topic?

options.text: The handouts are designed to spontaneously combust within 24 hours.
Reviewing the material within a few hours, and again within a few days, is important to getting the material into your long-term memory.

questions.question: Regarding exams and online quizzes

options.text: There is a penalty for answering a question incorrectly, so you should only answer a question if you know the answer.
There is NO penalty for answering a question incorrectly, so you should answer every question, even if you have to randomly guess what the correct answer might be.

questions.question: Where can you find important information about the course?

options.text: All of these answers are correct.
A list of the dates by which the online quizzes must be completed may be found in the course syllabus.
A list of exam dates may be found in the course syllabus.
A list of the assigned readings for each topic may be found in the course syllabus.

questions.question: When you receive emails from your professor, you should:

options.text: always read the entire email carefully

questions.question: There will be assigned readings from the textbook for most or all of the course topics.

options.text: Course readings will be determined later in the semester.
A list of the readings for each topic can be found in the course syllabus.
You will have to look at the Table of Contents for the textbook and try to guess which parts you should read for each topic.

questions.question: If you have trouble seeing a figure on a set of study questions, quiz or exam, you should:

options.text: Make sure you are using Google chrome
All of these answers are correct.

questions.question: All exams must be taken in-person, on the day and time listed in the course syllabus. Valid excuses for a make-up exam are:

options.text: being too sick to take the exam or being out of town for military service or certain university-approved activities (e.g., varsity sports competitions).
needing to be at work during the exam times.

questions.question: What resources are available on the course Canvas website?

options.text: All of these answers are correct.
options.comment: Correct. You will definitely want to access the course Canvas site on a regular basis. Correct. You will definitely want to access the course Canvas site on a regular basis.

options.text: Information regarding your scores on quizzes, exams and lab activities.
A copy of the course syllabus.
Other materials to help you master the course material.

questions.question: Which of the following looks like a good study plan for an average student hoping to earn an average grade of "C" in the course?

options.text: Spend almost all of your time on the course handouts.

For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 1.5 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.
options.comment: Yes! However, it should be noted that each student is different and so somewhat different plans may work better for some students.

options.text: Spend a large percentage of your time on reading the textbook.

questions.question: There will be a number of online quizzes throughout the semester.

options.text: The questions on the online quizzes are different from the questions from which the study questions are drawn.
You may work together with other students from the course on these quizzes.
You may ask one of the TAs to help you answer the quiz questions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: 0% of the questions on the exams will be taken from the study questions.
100% of the questions on the exams will be taken from the study questions.
Approximately 50% of the questions on the exams will be taken from the study questions.
Approximately 80% of the questions on the exams will be taken from the study questions.

questions.question: Each online quiz must be completed by a certain date.

options.text: There is no way to know the deadlines for each quiz.
The deadlines for each online quiz will be determined later in the semester.
There are no deadlines by which each online quiz must be completed.
The deadlines for each quiz are listed in the course syllabus.

questions.question: If some of the course material is unclear,

options.text: you can make an appointment to speak with the professor.
you can answer study questions and then go over the correct answers and the explanations of the correct answers.
you can look on the web for more information.
you can get help from TAs (a schedule will be posted on the course Canvas site as soon as it’s available).
all of these answers are correct.
you can go back over part or all of a recording to go back over particular concepts.
you can look back at your textbook for help.
You can get free tutoring through UMN SMART Learning Commons.
you can go back over the course handout and powerpoints.

questions.question: Regarding the online quizzes:

options.text: If you forget the deadline for a quiz, you can take it late

Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.
If you are sick when a quiz is due, you can take it late
If you are about to submit a quiz right before the deadline and the power or internet goes out (i.e. something happens that was completely outside of your control), you can take the quiz late

quiz_title: Quiz 2 (due Thursday, Sept. 11 at 11:59 PM): BIOL 1009 (070-082) General Biology (Fall 2025)

questions.question: MgCl2 is an example of
Electron shells

options.text: may have only certain average distances from the nucleus and may have only certain energy levels
may have any average distance from the nucleus and any energy level
may have any average distance from the nucleus but may have only certain energy levels
may have only certain average distances from the nucleus but may have any energy level

questions.question: When a reversible chemical reaction reaches equilibrium,

options.text: the forward and reverse reactions stop
the relative concentrations of reactants and products continues to change
the concentrations of reactants and products are equal
the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate

questions.question: How many electrons do carbon atoms have in their valence shell?
How many electrons do nitrogen atoms have in their valence shell?
Pure water at room temperature has a concentration of 10-7 hydrogen ions (H+) and 10-7 hydroxyl ions (OH-). Why is this?

options.text: Because at any given moment 1 in 1014 water molecules is broken apart into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.
Because water will absorb oxygen molecules from the atmosphere and some of those oxygen molecules will combine with hydrogen atoms from the water.
Because at any given moment 1 in 103.5 water molecules is broken apart into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.
Because at any given moment 1 in 107 water molecules is broken apart into hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.

questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydrogen ion [H+] concentration of 10-8 M?
If you mix a solid, hydrophilic substance “X” and a solid, hydrophobic substance “Y” with water

options.text: X will likely not dissolve in the water. Y will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where Y is the solvent and water is the solute.
X will likely not dissolve in the water. Y will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where Y is the solute and water is the solvent.
X will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where X is the solute and water is the solvent. Y will likely not dissolve in the water.
X will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where X is the solvent and water is the solute. Y will likely not dissolve in the water.

questions.question: Which of the following would you expect to dissolve poorly in water?

options.text: A substance with a lot of polar covalent bonds
A substance with a lot of nonpolar covalent bonds

questions.question: Discovery science

options.text: focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

options.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.question: A hypothesis

options.text: can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can NOT be proven to be correct

questions.question: A hypothesis must be testable and falsifiable to be scientifically valid. Being testable and falsifiable means that

options.text: some conceivable observation or experiment could reveal whether a given hypothesis is incorrect
only a controlled experiment can prove whether a hypothesis is correct or incorrect
the hypothesis has been proved wrong
there must be several options in the hypothesis to chose from, one of which is correct

questions.question: Polar molecules are often able to dissolve in water because

options.text: The polar molecules attract each other, allowing water molecules to adsorb to them.
The polar molecules repel each other, allowing them to interact with the water molecules.
The partially charged regions of polar molecules are able to form hydrogen bonds with water molecules.
Polar molecules are able to fill their valence shells by transferring electrons from water molecules.

questions.question: What is the pH of an aqueous solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH-] concentration of 10-12 M?
A solution with a pH of 12 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH-]?
The charge on a water molecule is best described as being:

options.text: Somewhat less than minus one near the oxygen atom and plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.
Minus one near the oxygen atom and somewhat less than plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.
Minus one near the oxygen atom and plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.
Somewhat less than minus one near the oxygen atom and somewhat less than plus one near each of the hydrogen atoms.

questions.question: A theory is

options.text: a poorly supported idea that has little backing but might be correct
a concept that, once established in the scientific literature, can be modified but never rejected, even when new scientific methods produce data that don’t fit
a well-supported concept that has broad explanatory power
not correct unless it is several years old

questions.question: Qualitative data may be collected

options.text: when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science
only when carrying out discovery science
only when carrying out hypothesis-based science
only when carrying out numerical science

questions.question: The method of scientific inquiry that describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observation and the analysis of data is known as
Which of the following statements about valence shells is FALSE?

options.text: Electrons in the valence shell (i.e. valence electrons) are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.
The valence shell is the outermost electron shell of an atom.
The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
The valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about chemical reactions is FALSE?

options.text: When hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water, the hydrogen and oxygen molecules are the “reactants” of the reaction.
When hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water, the water molecules are the “products” of the reaction.
Chemical reactions may only proceed in one direction.
Chemical reactions involve the making and breaking of chemical bonds.

questions.question: When two atoms share a pair of electrons, they
When an electron is moved further from the nucleus

options.text: its potential energy may change, depending on how the electron was moved

questions.question: Electrons exist only at fixed levels of potential energy. However, if an atom absorbs sufficient energy, a possible result is that

options.text: an electron may move to an electron shell closer to the nucleus.
the atom would become a negatively charged ion, or anion.
the atom may become a radioactive isotope.
an electron may move to an electron shell farther away from the nucleus.

quiz_title: Quiz 3 (due Thursday, Sept. 18 at 11:59 PM): BIOL 1009 (070-082) General Biology (Fall 2025)

questions.question: If I have trouble seeing a figure, I should:

options.text: Assume that the figure is missing from that question.
Re-size my browser window. If that doesn't work I should make sure I'm using Google chrome and have recently cleared the cache from my browser.

questions.question: Organic chemistry is defined as

options.text: the study of natural (as opposed to synthetic) compounds
the study of compounds made only by living cells

questions.question: Thalidomide and L-dopa, shown below, are examples of pharmaceutical drugs that occur as enantiomers, or molecules that

options.text: are mirror images of one another and have the same biological activity.
are mirror images of one another.

questions.question: Molecules consisting only of carbon and hydrogen are known as

Lipids that contain one or more C=C double bonds are referred to as
How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
What would be the sequence of the RNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template? 5’ AATTCGC 3’
What is the best description of a carbonyl group?

options.text: A carbon joined to a hydroxyl group by a single covalent bond
A nitrogen and two hydrogens joined to a carbon by covalent bonds
A carbon atom joined to an oxygen by a double covalent bond
An oxygen joined to a carbon by a single covalent bond

questions.question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be

options.text: All of these answers are correct

questions.question: Which of the following structures makes sense?
A general term for the repeating units that are assembled to form polymers is:

If you were asked to build a polymer that is two monomers long (ok, that wouldn’t really be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?
What would be the sequence of the DNA molecule made using the following DNA strand as a template? 5’ GAGGCTT 3’
Lipids that are commonly found in membranes include
If someone wants to eat lots of carbohydrates in preparation for running a marathon, that person could

options.text: all of these answers are correct

questions.question: The following functional group is known as
Which action could produce a carbonyl group?

options.text: the addition of a thiol to a hydroxyl
the replacement of the –O-H of a carboxyl group with hydrogen
the replacement of the nitrogen of an amine with oxygen
the replacement of an H of a methyl group with oxygen

questions.question: What functional group is commonly used in cells to transfer energy from one organic molecule to another?
The general structure of amino acids is shown in this figure. What functional groups are highlighted in salmon and yellow, respectively?

If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?
Glucose and fructose are examples of

options.text: all of these answers are correct

questions.question: Unsaturated fats

options.text: contain at least one covalent double bond joining two carbon atoms (i.e. C=C)
are missing at least one hydrogen atom
contain at least on cyclical fatty acid molecule
contain at least one branched fatty acid molecule

questions.question: The structural level of a protein that is least affected by a disruption in hydrogen bonding is the
Monosaccharides are added to growing polysaccharide chains via condensation (dehydration) reactions. Which of the following also occur via condensation (dehydration) reactions?

options.text: Attaching nucleotides to growing DNA molecules
All of these answers are correct
Attaching amino acids to growing polypeptide chains
Attaching fatty acids to glycerol molecules

quiz_title: Quiz 3 (due Thursday, Sept. 18 at 11:59 PM)

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as
Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.text: Carboxyl groups tend to act as acids.
Amino groups tend to act as bases.
Hydroxyl groups can form hydrogen bonds.

questions.question: Polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins are similar in that they

options.text: are synthesized from monomers by the process of hydrolysis
are decomposed into their subunits by dehydration reactions
all contain nitrogen in their monomer building blocks
are synthesized from monomers by dehydration reactions

questions.question: The subunit of polypeptides contains all of the following EXCEPT

options.text: an "R" group connected to one of the carbons.

questions.question: What is the correct formula for a monosaccharide that is 4 carbons long?
What is the likely order of the following molecules, in order of largest to smallest?
Which of the following statements best describes how fats are synthesized?

options.text: Fats are synthesized from glycerol and fatty acid molecules via dehydration reactions.
Fats are synthesized from glycerol and fatty alcohol molecules via hydrolysis reactions.
Fats are synthesized from glycerol and fatty acid molecules via hydrolysis reactions.
Fats are synthesized from glycerol and fatty alcohol molecules via dehydration reactions.

questions.question: If two molecules are mirror images of each other, the two molecules may be
The molecules shown below are best described as
The primary structure of a protein refers to

options.text: the folded and coiled segment of a polypeptide
the overall shape of the protein formed by the aggregation of the polypeptides in the protein

questions.question: If starch and cellulose are both polymers of glucose, how come people can digest starch but not cellulose?

options.text: When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into non-sugar molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into xylose molecules that are impossible for us to digest.

The glucose monomers that form starch are joined together by different covalent bonds than the glucose monomers that form cellulose and the enzymes in our bodies that are able to hydrolyze (break) the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in starch are not able to hydrolyze the covalent bonds between the glucose monomers in cellulose.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into lactose molecules, which are hard for many people to digest.

questions.question: Which of the molecules listed below can form isomers? CH4 C3H8 C4H10

options.text: CH4 and C3H8 cannot form isomers, but C4H10can form isomers
None of them can form isomers.
CH4 cannot form isomers, but C3H8 and C4H10can form isomers
All of them can form isomers

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as
Compounds with hydroxyl groups are known as
On what basis are different molecules grouped as “lipids”?

options.text: Compounds designated as lipids are grouped together because they mix poorly, if at all, with water.
Compounds designated as lipids are grouped together because they are located in membranes.
Compounds designated as lipids are grouped together because they are formed from fatty acids.
Compounds designated as lipids are grouped together because they have a glycerol backbone.

questions.question: Which of the following are NOT components of nucleotides?

options.text: an “R” group attached to a central carbon atom

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the nucleotides used in RNA synthesis is correct?

options.text: The nucleotides used in RNA synthesis have ribose as their sugar component and do not include nucleotides that have thymine as their nitrogenous base.
The nucleotides used in RNA synthesis have deoxyribose as their sugar component and do not include nucleotides that have uracil as their nitrogenous base.
The nucleotides used in RNA synthesis have deoxyribose as their sugar component and do not include nucleotides that have thymine as their nitrogenous base.
The nucleotides used in RNA synthesis have ribose as their sugar component and do not include nucleotides that have uracil as their nitrogenous base.

quiz_title: Quiz 3 (due Thursday, Sept. 18 at 11:59 PM): BIOL 1009 (070-082) General Biology (Fall 2025)_2

questions.question: A dehydration reaction joins two glucose molecules to form maltose. The formula for glucose is C6H12O6. What is the correct formula for maltose?
The covalent linkages between nucleotides forming a DNA molecule are known as
Nucleotides in a single DNA chain are joined together by

options.text: a covalent bond between the nitrogenous base of one nucleotide and the nitrogenous base of the next nucleotide
a covalent bond between the phosphate group of one nucleotide and the sugar group of the next nucleotide
hydrogen bonds between the nitrogenous base of one nucleotide and the nitrogenous base of the next nucleotide
hydrogen bonds between the phosphate group of one nucleotide and the sugar group of the next nucleotide

questions.question: If two molecules have the same numbers of atoms of the same elements and the SAME covalent partnerships but different structures, the two molecules may be

options.text: It is the 1st carbon on the left
It is the 2nd carbon from the left
It is the 4th carbon from the left
It is the 3rd carbon from the left

options.text: the folded and coiled segment of a polypeptide
the overall shape of the protein formed by the aggregation of the polypeptides in the protein

questions.question: The central carbon in amino acids is asymmetric in all amino acids except:
The molecules shown below are best described as
If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?
What is a triacylglycerol?

options.text: A lipid made with three fatty acids and glycerol
A protein with a tertiary structure
A lipid that makes up much of the plasma membrane
A molecule formed from three alcohols by dehydration reactions.

quiz_title: SQ topic 1a level 1a (course resources and policies): BIOL 1009 (070-082) General Biology (Fall 2025)
SQ topic 1a level 1b (course resources and policies): BIOL 1009 (070-082) General Biology (Fall 2025)

questions.question: What are two methods of scientific inquiry?
An explanation that is broad in scope and is supported by a large body of evidence is known in science as a

options.text: all of these answers are correct

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of discovery science?

options.text: Some of Charles Darwin’s work that helped lead to the theory of natural selection
Observations that led to the conclusion that all organism are made of cells
Testing the prediction that mimicking the coloring of poisonous snakes will protect non-poisonous snakes from predation.
Some of Jane Goodall’s work observing chimpanzee behavior

questions.question: In science, a “theory”

options.text: all of these answers are correct
is supported by a large body of evidence

questions.question: Quantitative data may be collected

options.text: only when carrying out numerical science
only when carrying out discovery science
only when carrying out hypothesis-based science
when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science

questions.question: What types of data may be collected when doing discovery science?

options.text: Only data that is partially qualitative and partially quantitative

questions.question: In science, a possible answer to a specific question is know as a

options.text: all of these answers are correct

quiz_title: SQ topic 1b level 1b (Chapter 1): BIOL 1009 (070-082) General Biology (Fall 2025)

questions.question: What types of data may be collected when doing hypothesis-based science?

options.text: Only data that is partially qualitative and partially quantitative

questions.question: The process whereby science experts determine whether a manuscript is suitable for publication in a scientific journal is known as
Which of the following is an example of qualitative data?

options.text: The fish swam in a zigzag motion.
The six pairs of robins hatched an average of three chicks.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the logic of hypothesis-based science?

options.text: If my hypothesis is correct, I can expect certain results.
If my observations are accurate, they will support my hypothesis.
If I generate a testable hypothesis, tests and observations will support it.
If my prediction is correct, it will lead to a testable hypothesis.

questions.question: During peer-review of a manuscript

options.text: typically two to three experts review the manuscript
the conclusions drawn in the manuscript are carefully considered to determine whether they are adequately supported by the data
all of these answers are correct
the experiments described in the manuscript are evaluated to determine whether they were rigorously performed

questions.question: Which of the following statements best distinguishes hypotheses from theories in science?

options.text: Hypotheses usually are relatively narrow in scope; theories have broad explanatory power.
Hypotheses are guesses; theories are correct answers.
Theories are proved true in all cases; hypotheses are usually falsified by tests.
Theories are hypotheses that have been proven.

options.text: is always the lowest energy shell the atom has
may contain no more than 2 electrons
may occur at any distance from the nucleus, depending on how many electrons the atom has

concentration of OH- has increased tenfold (10X) compared to what it was at pH 9.

questions.question: What causes water molecules to be polar molecules?

options.text: Oxygen is less electronegative than hydrogen.
Water molecules can form hydrogen bonds with each other.

questions.question: A mole of water (H2O) molecules and a mole of glucose molecules (C6H12O6)

options.text: have an equal number of molecules
have an equal number of atoms
have about ten times as many molecules in the mole of glucose than in the mole of water

questions.question: Which of the following represents a polar bond?

options.comment: Yes! Oxygen is substantially more electronegative than carbon. As a result, the pair of electrons forming the covalent bond between oxygen and carbon will spend significantly more time closer to the oxygen atom than the carbon atom. This means the bond will be a polar covalent bond.

questions.question: When a sodium atom and a chlorine atom interact to complete their valence shells

options.text: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into an anion and the chlorine atom into a cation and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond

questions.question: Why does the structure shown below fail to make sense chemically?H-C=C-H

options.text: Each hydrogen atom only has 1 covalent bond.
Carbon is more electronegative than hydrogen and should thus remove electrons from hydrogen, rather than forming a covalent bond with hydrogen.
The two carbon atoms share more than 1 bond.
Each carbon atom only has 3 covalent bonds.

questions.question: With regards to orbitals, which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.text: An orbital is occupied by one or two electrons.
An orbital can be depicted as a cloud where an electron may be located.
An orbital is a region surrounding the nucleus where the probability of finding an electron is high.
An orbital is a defined path that an electron follows as it orbits the nucleus.

questions.question: The molar mass of glucose is 180 g/mol. Which of the following procedures should you carry out to make a 1 M (molar) solution of glucose?

options.text: Dissolve 1 g of glucose in 1 L of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 1 L of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 180 g of water.
Dissolve 180 g of glucose in 0.8 L of water, and then add more water until the total volume of the solution is 1 L.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do carbon atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
The lowest energy mechanism by which a carbon atom may complete its valence shell is to

options.text: transfer the 4 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 4 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
transfer the 2 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 2 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms
form 4 covalent bonds with other atoms

Enzymes speed up chemical reactions and need to be replenished as they are used up in the reactions.
Enzymes alter the relative concentrations of products and reactants that are present at equilibrium.
Enzymes speed up chemical reactions without being used up in the reactions.

options.text: A polymer is a long molecule consisting of many similar or identical building blocks held together by van der Waals forces.

A polymer is a long molecule consisting of many similar or identical building blocks linked by hydrogen bonds.

options.text: The phospholipids are arranged in a bilayer, with their hydrocarbon tails on the outside of the bilayer and their phosphate groups pointing toward the interior of the membrane.
The phospholipids are arranged in a bilayer, with their hydrocarbon tails pointing toward the interior of the membrane and their phosphate groups on the outside of the bilayer.
The phospholipids are arranged in a monolayer, with their hydrocarbon tails on the outside of the cell and their phosphate groups pointing toward the interior of the cell.
